They will stand in the meat grinder and unleash hell until the enemy is dead or they are. More often than not, it's the former.But the Human-Covenant war was more than a series of head-on charges. Sabotage, reconnaissance, assassination, guerilla warfare, infiltration, VIP extraction. These and more were just as common and often more important than frontline engagements. Missions like these required cunning, adaptability, versatility, subtlety. Spartans were all these things. Commandoes who could fill any role and do it better than anyone else. Cycling out thirty Spartan-II's with thirty Astartes changes f*ck-all about the space engagements, which humanity was still cripplingly weak at. Even replacing all the II's, III's and Orions with Astartes wouldn't have mattered in the long run. Space Marines are devastatingly effective at a handful of things. But we are much wiser now."Oh, the young and foolish. After nearly four more years down the 40k rabbit hole, this answer makes me want to relax in a Jacuzzi filled with burning promethium. Alright, time to fix this.Space marines outstrip Spartans in ability and equipment. They are eight foot tall gene warriors who spit acid and breathe vacuum and don’t care about arbitrary concepts like “gaping hole” and “missing limbs.” They’re clad in what could be described as a man-portable pillbox made of unobtanium that is designed to eat tank rounds and shrug off plasma. Their favorite weapons include an automatic RPG that turns armored opponents to mist and a chainsaw made of knives hard enough and sharp enough to chew through solid diamond. Despite being refrigerator-sized transhumans that weigh as much as two cows stacked on top of one another, space marines can move faster than the eye can process and can outrun an incoming missile. An Astartes would crack open a Spartan like a can of pringles, eat his head, digest his memories and use those memories to obtain the Spartan’s WiFi password.Basically, if a space marine acted the same way as a Spartan, he’d do it a hundred times better.But that’s the caveat: IF a space marine acted the same way as a Spartan. And this brings us to the Codex.The Codex Astartes, the military treatise that mandates how space marines organize and conduct themselves, can generally be regarded as the 40k equivalent to Spartan combat doctrine. It’s basically a mix of Art of War and the Holy Bible. Every space marine chapter has a different approach to adopting the Codex. Some, like the Ultramarines or Hammers of Dorn, hold the Codex as holy writ and adhere to it religiously. Others, like the Crimson Fists or Carcharodons, have a more liberal interpretation of the Codex and bend the rules as necessary. And there are some like the Black Templars and Space Wolves who have a passing respect for the Codex at best but otherwise ignore it entirely and do their own thing.The reason why the Codex is important is because it covers a lot of things but DOESN’T cover everything. And a lot of what it covers and mandates can be exceptionally well-planned and pragmatic or pants-on-head stupid and careless. So how a space marine behaves while filling in as a Spartan largely depends on the Codex compliance of his native chapter.An all-in chapter like the Ultramarines would be highly disciplined with a strategy for almost everything but would suffer from a crippling lack of improvisation when faced with something the Codex doesn’t account for, which is likely in Halo where a space marine is a fish out of water. Likely to do well until their first big trip-up, in which case they fail and fail hard.A dissonant chapter could theoretically be anything, but in the case of my two earlier examples (Black Templars and Space Wolves), they would actually be pretty similar to my 2018 description of space marines: melee-obsessed murdermachines who charge into the thick of it en masse and hack everything to pieces. Excellent shock troops, but with the exception of Space Wolf scouts, not at all accustomed to the roles Spartans are meant to take and likely to die in their first engagement without support from other military forces. Especially if they’re only thirty strong like Spartans are.Your best bet would be a chapter that obeys the Codex but doesn't follow it blindly. These would be adaptable and skilled, with a wide knowledge base and the ability to improvise as the situation demands. They can be scouts, saboteurs, assassins, commandos, shock troops: everything a Spartan needs to be. In this case, they could be the heroes humanity needs.Side note: don’t try to randomize marines from different chapters. Unless they have a unique system akin to the Deathwatch, it’ll be pure chaos. Space marine chapters are often so wildly different in culture and doctrine that there’d be little hope for cohesion. They could work together, but never with the same coordination as chapter brothers, let alone Spartans.
